newsitem.title: UK: Oil markets unmoved by prospect of more Iraqi oil.
newsitem.headline: Oil markets unmoved by prospect of more Iraqi oil.

text.p: World oil markets were unruffled on Tuesday by news that the United Nations was likely to extend its "oil-for-food" deal with Iraq.
The Security Council is expected to adopt a resolution as early as Wednesday allowing Iraq to sell another $2 billion worth of oil over the next six months.
Brent Blend crude, the world benchmark grade, was down eight cents at $19.44 a barrel at 0916 GMT in London. It has averaged $19.39 in the past four months.
The rollover of the Iraqi deal is "already built into the market," said Bob Finch, head trader at Vitol SA, the world's largest independent oil trading and refining company.
The only uncertainty in oil markets had been whether the United States would approve an extension of the plan.
But on Monday a source familiar with Washington policy said the U.S. "will be looking favourably toward the rollover".
The current deal, a humanitarian exception to the broader economic sanctions in place since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990, expires on June 7.
Under its terms, Baghdad was allowed to use oil earnings to buy food, medicines and other necessities for ordinary Iraqis who have suffered under the sanctions regime.
Oil markets have been volatile in recent weeks and dealers
are waiting to see if the normal seasonal pick up in gasoline demand in the United States will be enough to underpin prices.
"There's no urge to move out of the current price range," said Nigel Saperia, managing director of the oil division at Bankers Trust International in London.
"Fundamentally there's too much oil around but frankly there always is at this time of year," he added.
Despite an overhang of prompt oil, due in part to overproduction by OPEC, the forward outlook is more balanced with winter demand likely to mop up unsold barrels, said traders.
Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil producer and OPEC heavyweight, expects rising world oil demand to keep crude prices buoyant for the remainder of the year, a Gulf source said recently.
The source, familiar with oil policy in the kingdom, said Saudi expectations for demand on Organisation of the Petroleum Exporting Countries crude this year had been revised higher.
Saudi Arabia saw demand on OPEC oil at around 27 million barrels a day (bpd) on average this year compared to a previous projection of 26.3 million bpd made at the end of last year.
Whereas world demand looked set to rise by some two million bpd this year, extra supplies in 1997 from non-OPEC nations would reach only one million bpd.
"If you have what most people see as 27 million bpd from OPEC and no more than an extra one million coming from non-OPEC then the market will continue balanced to tight," the Gulf source said.
For the second year running analysts have cut their forecasts for non-OPEC supply growth because new North Sea fields have failed to come on stream when planned.
Dealers are looking for two sets of industry figures this week to shed light on the market.
Later on Tuesday the American Petroleum Institute publishes its latest figures for gasoline stocks, which have been running well below year ago levels.
On Friday the International Energy Agency in Paris, the West's oil watchdog, is due to release figures estimating global oil demand for next winter and beyond.
"The key may well be how oil demand in Asia develops over the rest of the year," said Scott Carter, senior oil trader at U.S. refiner Tosco in London.
Asia is set to stay one of the fastest growing areas of oil demand over the next few years with Western demand rising relatively slowly.
June 3 June 2
(0916 GMT) (close)
Dated Brent $19.17 $19.25
IPE July Brent $19.44 $19.52
NYMEX July light crude ------ $20.98
--London newsroom, - 44 171 542 4984
